work.name: Visby.io
work.summary: Performed experiments to explore models for decoding holographic light field video.
highlights: Wrote C++ code and profiled low-level hardware activity to optimize performance, stability, and data throughput as part of a critical feature for the decoding pipeline.
Designed and implemented a data ETL system in Python for tracking stability metrics.
Gained exposure to CUDA programming, learning new APls on the fly (e.g libavcodec, OpenSSL) and translating high-level requirements into manageable subtasks.
Learned to write well-documented code for a large repository, apply best-practice system design principles, and take on many roles in a demanding, fast-paced agile environment.

work.name: Blue Sky Studio
work.summary: Developed and made improvements to proprietary animation pipeline tools for Blue Sky Studios, an animation studio behind films such as Ice Age and The Peanuts Movie.
highlights: Collaborated with software engineers and artists to build the groundwork for a node-based material designer and create an intuititve UI for texture artist (Python/PyQt).

work.name: Bootcamp.com
work.summary: Creating physics content at Bootcamp.com, an exam preparation service for aspiring optometry students preparing for the Optometry Admissions Test (OAT).
highlights: Lead a team of 3 to write and edit hundreds of physics problems and solutions used by thousands of pre-optometry students.
Analyze student performance data to identify weak content areas and organize tasks to strategically improve question accuracy and relevancy.
Design new physics diagrams and illustrations using Adobe Illustrator to support student learning and comprehension.

technical work.name: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University
technical work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
